elements.content: The self-assembly of metallosupramolecules from reactions of flexible 2-pyridyl ligands and silver salts is described. When 1,3-bis(2-pyridyl)propane (L 1 ), tris[(2-pyridyl)methyl]methane (L 2 ), and 1,3-bis(2-pyridyl)-2-tolylpropane (L 3 ) are used in combination with silver ions, novel discrete metallocyclic complexes are formed in crystals. Moreover, the self-assembly of 1,3-bis(2-pyridyl)-2-phenylpropane (L 4 ) with silver nitrate yields a coordination polymer. The examination of its solution shows that this coordination polymer is formed via the solution-based discrete metallocyclic species.

elements.content: During the past decades, there has been considerable interest in the controlled self-assembly of metallosupramolecular species, such as coordination cages and coordination polymers. The most common approach to synthesize such compounds has been the rational combination of organic ligands bearing coordination sites and metal cations. When using structurally flexible ligands, depending on the conformation of the connecting fragment, one may expect the formation of either discrete macrocyclic or infinite polymeric structures. Thus, numerous flexible ligands have been employed to provide closed, two-dimensional rings and three-dimensional cage compounds for discrete systems, as well as a large assortment of coordination polymers, grids, and lattices for infinite systems. Despite this, very little has been reported concerning the relationship and conversion between the two systems. Very recently, Puddephatt et al. and James et al. reported interesting examples of the conversion of the discrete coordination species containing flexible ligands to the coordination polymer via the ring opening mechanism.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past decades, there has been considerable interest in the controlled self-assembly of metallosupramolecular species, such as coordination cages and coordination polymers. The most common approach to synthesize such compounds has been the rational combination of organic ligands bearing coordination sites and metal cations. When using structurally flexible ligands, depending on the conformation of the connecting fragment, one may expect the formation of either discrete macrocyclic or infinite polymeric structures. Thus, numerous flexible ligands have been employed to provide closed, two-dimensional rings and three-dimensional cage compounds for discrete systems, as well as a large assortment of coordination polymers, grids, and lattices for infinite systems. Despite this, very little has been reported concerning the relationship and conversion between the two systems. Very recently, Puddephatt et al. and James et al. reported interesting examples of the conversion of the discrete coordination species containing flexible ligands to the coordination polymer via the ring opening mechanism.

elements.content: In this context, we prepared several flexible 2-pyridyl ligands and investigated their complexes with silver salts. The four 2-pyridyl ligands we chose in this study, such as 1,3-bis(2-pyridyl)propane (L 1 ), tris[(2-pyridyl)methyl]methane (L 2 ), 1,3-bis(2-pyridyl)-2-tolylpropane (L 3 ), and 1,3-bis(2-pyridyl)-2-phenylpropane (L 4 ), are structurally closely related to each other.

elements.content: Herein, we report the formation of novel discrete metallomacrocycles of [Ag2(L1)2](ClO4)2 (1), [Ag3(L2)2](ClO4)3 (2), and [Ag2(L3)2](NO3)2 (3) and a coordination polymer of {[AgL4](NO3)}∞ (4) derived from the reaction of silver(I) salts with L 1 , L 2 , L 3 , and L 4 , respectively. Furthermore, we wish to report the conversion of solution-based discrete supramolecular units into the polymeric species of 4 at the solution−crystal interface.

Furthermore, we wish to report the conversion of solution-based discrete supramolecular units into the polymeric species of 4 at the solution-crystal interface.

elements.content: General. All the synthetic reactions were done under nitrogen using standard Schlenk-type flasks without exposure to light. Workup procedures were done in air. All solvents were dried and distilled according to standard methods before use. Reagents were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and Strem Chemical Co. and were used as received. 1H NMR spectra were obtained with a Bruker 300 or 500 spectrometer. Elemental analyses were done at National Center for Inter-University Research Facilities, Seoul National University. VPO experiments were performed in MeOH at 318 K over a concentration range 4−14 g/kg (sample/solvent) using a Knauer K-7000 twin-thermistor hanging-drop vapor pressure osmometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General. All the synthetic reactions were done under nitrogen using standard Schlenk-type flasks without exposure to light. Workup procedures were done in air. All solvents were dried and distilled according to standard methods before use. Reagents were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and Strem Chemical Co. and were used as received. 1H NMR spectra were obtained with a Bruker 300 or 500 spectrometer. Elemental analyses were done at National Center for Inter-University Research Facilities, Seoul National University. VPO experiments were performed in MeOH at 318 K over a concentration range 4-14 g/kg (sample/solvent) using a Knauer K-7000 twin-thermistor hanging-drop vapor pressure osmometer.

elements.content:
Ligands L 1 , L 2 , and L 4 were previously reported. Formation of these compounds was verified by comparing NMR spectra.

Synthesis of L 3 . Diisoproylamine (3.8 mL, 2.7 mmol) and n-BuLi (11.4 mL, 2.5 M in hexane) were dissolved in a 60 mL of THF in a Schlenk flask at −78 °C. After the solution was stirred for 30 min at −78 °C, 2-picoline (2.5 mL, 25 mmol) was added to the solution. The solution was allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for 30 min. To the solution was added p-tolualdehyde (1.0 mL, 8.4 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred overnight and quenched with water (100 mL). After the reaction mixture was washed with saturated NaHCO3 (100 mL), CH2Cl2 (100 mL) was added to extract the dipyridyl compound. The CH2Cl2 layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, concentrated, and chromatographed on a silica gel column eluting with hexane and diethyl ether (v/v, 1:1). Removal of the solvent gave the product in 36% yield (0.86 g). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.47 (d, 4.9 Hz, 2 H), 7.43 (t, 7.7 Hz, 2 H), 7.03−6.93 (m, 8 H), 3.70 (quint, 7.0 Hz, 1 H), 3.16 (m, 4 H), 2.24 (s, 3 H) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3):  δ 161.2, 150.0, 141.2, 136.9, 136.4, 129.8, 128.5, 124.6, 121.9, 46.8, 45.9, 22.0 ppm. HRMS M+ calcd 288.1626, obsd 288.1622.

elements.content: Synthesis of 1. To a solution of L 1 (20 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 4 mL of nitromethane was carefully added a solution of AgClO4 (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 4 mL of methanol. elements.content: X-ray Data Collection, Structure Determination, and Refinement for 1, 2, 3, and 4. The diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CCD single-crystal X-ray diffractometer. In the cases of 3 and 4, diffractions were measured by an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 automated diffractometer. Unit cells were determined by centering 25 reflections in the appropriate 2θ range. Other relevant experimental details are listed in Table . The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined against all F 2 data (SHELXS-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were located on ideal positions using a riding model with 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic temperature factors of the atoms to which they are attached. Selected bond length and angles are in Table .

Ligand Synthesis. All of the ligands employed in this study have the common structural feature, namely that they contain pyridine units as the coordination sites interconnected through the propyl spacer. Ligand syntheses have been carried out through the modification of the previously reported procedure (Scheme ). 6
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

 Ligand Synthesis. All of the ligands employed in this study have the common structural feature, namely that they contain pyridine units as the coordination sites interconnected through the propyl spacer. Ligand syntheses have been carried out through the modification of the previously reported procedure (Scheme ). 6

elements.content: Owing to the flexible nature of their spacer, they may be able to adopt various conformations in solutions. Depending on their conformation in the self-assembly with metal ions, one may expect the formation of either discrete complexes of the metallomacrocycle type for the convergent disposition of the coordination sites or infinite coordination networks for the divergent orientation of the monodentate sites.

elements.content: Complexes of L 1 and L 2 with AgClO 4 . Slow diffusion of solutions of L 1 and L 2 in MeOH into a H2O solution of AgClO4 afforded crystalline complexes of 1 and 2, respectively. The formulation of [Ag2 L 1 2](ClO4)2 (1) and [Ag3 L 2 2](ClO4)2 (2) was confirmed by the elemental analysis and the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method. The X-ray structural analysis revealed the occurrence of [2 + 2] and [2 + 3] self-assembly and the formation of discrete supramolecular arrays.

The formulation of [Ag2 L  1   2](ClO4)2 (1) and [Ag3 L  2   2](ClO4)2 (2) was confirmed by the elemental analysis and the single-crystal X-ray diffraction method. The X-ray structural analysis revealed the occurrence of [2 + 2] and [2 + 3] self-assembly and the formation of discrete supramolecular arrays.

elements.content: Figure shows the 2:2 self-assembled metallomacrocyclic structure of 1. Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table . Two molecules of L 1 with two pyridine units oriented in a convergent fashion cooperatively coordinate to two silver cations around a pseudoinversion center, such that they form a 16-membered parallelogram-shaped macrocycle. In a cyclic unit, the Ag−Ag distance is 7.455 Å, and the shortest distance between carbon atoms at opposite sides is 4.060 Å. Each silver center can be regarded as quasi-tricoordinated with two nitrogen atoms in two distinct ligands and in weak contact with a perchlorate oxygen. There is almost no difference between the two crystallographically independent silver centers. The Ag−N bond lengths of 2.111(12)−2.194(11) Å are within the range of reported values, and the N−Ag−N angles are 165.7(4)° and 166.5(4)°. The contact distances between silver and oxygen atoms of perchlorate are 2.846(14) and 2.883(13) Å, which indicates the presence of weak nonbonding Ag−O interactions. Four pyridyl rings forming a cycle are roughly parallel with 0.50−16.76° dihedral angles, such that macrocycles of 1 exhibit a nearly flat structure. Each macrocycle is stacked along the c-axis via the π−π interactions between pyridine rings. The pyridine rings in adjacent cycles are stacked in a “head-to-tail” manner with center-to-center distances of 3.78 and 3.79 Å and dihedral angles of 0.50° and 1.08°, which nearly matches the most favorable stacking geometry postulated by Janiak.

elements.content: Figure depicts the discrete trinuclear supramolecular cage structure of 2. The M3L2 type cagelike complexes are not well documented up to now. Two tripodal L 2 ligands are aggregated by the simultaneous coordination of their pyridine nitrogen atoms to three silver ions to form C 3 symmetric cage structure. Each L 3 molecule adopts a propellerlike conformation, such that its pyridyl arms are symmetrically oriented around a 3-fold symmetry axis passing through its apical carbon atom. Additionally, three silver ions are triangularly arranged around the axis. The distance between silver centers in a cage unit is 4.580(1) Å. Each silver center is in an almost linear coordination environment with a N−Ag−N bond angle of 176.7(2)° and Ag−N bond distances of 2.120(6) and 2.135(6) Å. Perchlorate anions just serve as counteranions, such that there is no significant contact between the silver cation and perchlorate anions. Recently, a similar trinuclear structure formed from tris(N-propylimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine and silver cation was reported by Mak et al. In Mak's structure, three silver atoms are in close contact with each other through Ag−Ag interatomic interactions, so it has no space. In contrast, in a complex of 2, tripodal arms of L 2 splay out, and silver centers are located far apart from each other without significant mutual interaction. As a result, 2 possesses an inner cavity in its center (Ag−Ag, 4.58 Å; C(7)−C(14), 5.00 Å). It is noteworthy that the two L 2 species in a cage have the same orientation, and thus, the inner cavity of 2 is chiral. Very intriguingly, every cavity in a crystal has the same chirality and is noncentrosymmetrically arranged. This should be due to the occurrence of the spontaneous chiral resolution in the crystallization stage. We believe that the chiral nature of crystal 2 might induce useful bulk properties such as nonlinear optical properties, piezoelectricity, and triboluminescence when incorporating suitable guest molecules.

elements.content: Complexes of L 3 and L 4 with AgNO 3 . When MeOH solutions containing L 3 and L 4 were layered onto a H2O solution of AgNO3 and stood for several days, crystals of 3 and 4 were obtained, respectively. L 3 and L 4 have quite a similar structure, and reactions with silver ion were carried out under the same conditions. Elemental analyses showed that both of them have a 1:1 silver-to-ligand ratio. Thus, at first, they were expected to form complexes with much resemblance to each other. However, far from our expectation, X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that their complexes are quite different from each other. While a discrete cyclic dinuclear array is formed in the crystal of 3, a polymeric chain structure is constructed in the crystal of 4.

While a discrete cyclic dinuclear array is formed in the crystal of 3, a polymeric chain structure is constructed in the crystal of 4.

elements.content: Figure shows the [2 + 2] assembled supramolecular array of 3, [Ag2 L 3 2](NO3)2. The cyclic structural motif of 3 is quite similar to that found in 1 except for the protruding toluenyl rings, such that two L 3 molecules make a tetragonal macrocycle with two silver cations around an inversion center. The Ag−N bond length is 2.166(5) Å, and the N−Ag−N angle is 173.73(18)°. Each nitrate anion makes weak contact with two silver centers and a bridge between two distinct units. The contact distances between the silver and oxygen atoms of perchlorate are 2.723(6) and 2.822(6) Å. Through this nonbonding interaction, infinite quasi-one-dimensional chain arrays are formed which may stabilize the complex in the crystal (Figure ).

elements.content: In the crystal of 4, {[AgL 4 ](NO3)}∞, each L 4 ligand with two pyridine rings oriented in a divergent fashion connects two Ag(I) ions to form an infinite serpentine chain structure along the c-axis (Figure ). In a chain structure, there exist two types of crystallographically independent silver centers. The environments around the silver centers are strongly deviated from the linear coordination geometry, and each silver center makes N−Ag−N bond angles of 167.6(3)° and 124.5(2)°, respectively (Figure ). Such bending of the N−Ag−N bond should be due to the influence of the coordination of nitrate anions with silver centers. In the complex of 4, nitrate ions act not only as counteranions but also produce relatively strong interactions with silver centers. As shown in Table , the Ag−O contact distances in complex 4 are much shorter than those found in 3. The nitrate ions bridge the distinct chains, which are constructed along the Ag−N bonds and form a latticelike two-dimensional structure (Figure ).

elements.content: The discrete metallocyclic arrays found in crystals of 1, 2, and 3 represent the occurrence of the thermodynamically most favorable self-assembly. Many previous examples show that the smallest closed cyclic structures are preferred over any competing species in solution because their formation is the means of maximum enthalpy gain with a minimum possible entropy loss. Thus, it is inferred that the metallomacrocycles of 1, 2, and 3 are formed in solution first and then slowly crystallized out.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The discrete metallocyclic arrays found in crystals of 1, 2, and 3 represent the occurrence of the thermodynamically most favorable self-assembly. Many previous examples show that the smallest closed cyclic structures are preferred over any competing species in solution because their formation is the means of maximum enthalpy gain with a minimum possible entropy loss. Thus, it is inferred that the  metallomacrocycles of 1, 2, and 3 are formed in solution first and then slowly crystallized out.

elements.content: On the contrary, the crystal of 4 shows the formation of a coordination polymer. We believe that its polymeric structure exists only in the solid state and oligomeric coordination units existing in the reaction solution differ from the resulting coordination polymer. The polymeric complex of 4 is sparingly soluble in H2O, probably with fragmentation to smaller units. Its solution was investigated through NMR analysis. The 1H NMR spectrum of the D2O solution of 4 exhibits a single pyridine environment indicating the presence of highly symmetric species. In addition, the spectrum closely resembles that of 3. This observation appears to indicate that the dominant species in the solution of 4 would adopt a closed metallocyclic structure like 3. For additional confirmation, a mass spectrometry experiment was carried out. The MS spectrum of the aqueous solution of 4 exhibits mass peaks assigned to [Ag2 L 4 2](NO3)+ and [Ag2 L 4 2]2+ and no evidence for the presence of species with higher nuclearity. Vapor pressure osmometric study showed a molecular weight of 268 which was close to the average molecular weight (278) of [Ag2 L 4 2]2+ and two counteranions. All of these observations support a dynamic system in which the dominant solution species of 4 is a dinuclear metallocycle of [Ag2 L 4 2](NO3)2. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that there is an equilibrium between the solution-based discrete binuclear species of [Ag2 L 4 2](NO3)2 and the insoluble polymeric species of {[AgL 4 ](NO3)}∞, and the insolubility of the polymer under the reaction condition would lead to the shift of the equilibrium toward the crystallization of the coordination polymer.

elements.content:
The differences arising between 3 and 4 are not simple to rationalize. Probably a major difference comes from the solubility differences of their discrete and polymeric species.

In conclusion, we employed the flexible pyridyl ligands to achieve self-assembly with silver ions. L 1 , L 2 , and L 3 afforded the thermodynamically most favored discrete metallocycles, and their novel structures in the solid state are observed. In contrast to this, the self-assembly of L 4 with silver nitrate generated a coordination polymer crystal. The examination of its solution species showed that this polymer species appears to be formed via the solution-based discrete metallocyclic species. This work shows a rare example of a mechanism by which coordination polymers might form. We deduce that the structure of the solution-based discrete precursor of polymers should define the structural characteristics such as the sequence of building blocks. By controlling the discrete species in reaction solution and their conversion conditions, we might be able to regulate the structure and properties of the resulting crystalline polymer. Further research is under way toward this end.

cln_elements.content:
Ligands L 1 , L 2 , and L 4 were previously reported. Formation of these compounds was verified by comparing NMR spectra.

Synthesis of L 3 . Diisoproylamine (3.8 mL, 2.7 mmol) and n-BuLi (11.4 mL, 2.5 M in hexane) were dissolved in a 60 mL of THF in a Schlenk flask at −78 °C. After the solution was stirred for 30 min at −78 °C, 2-picoline (2.5 mL, 25 mmol) was added to the solution. The solution was allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for 30 min. To the solution was added p-tolualdehyde (1.0 mL, 8.4 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred overnight and quenched with water (100 mL). After the reaction mixture was washed with saturated NaHCO3 (100 mL), CH2Cl2 (100 mL) was added to extract the dipyridyl compound. The CH2Cl2 layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, concentrated, and chromatographed on a silica gel column eluting with hexane and diethyl ether (v/v, 1:1). Removal of the solvent gave the product in 36% yield (0.86 g). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.47 (d, 4.9 Hz, 2 H), 7.43 (t, 7.7 Hz, 2 H), 7.03−6.93 (m, 8 H), 3.70 (quint, 7.0 Hz, 1 H), 3.16 (m, 4 H), 2.24 (s, 3 H) ppm. 13C NMR (CDCl3):  δ 161.2, 150.0, 141.2, 136.9, 136.4, 129.8, 128.5, 124.6, 121.9, 46.8, 45.9, 22.0 ppm. HRMS M+ calcd 288.1626, obsd 288.1622.

Synthesis of 1. To a solution of L 1 (20 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 4 mL of nitromethane was carefully added a solution of AgClO4 (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 4 mL of methanol. The resulting solution was stored in an open test tube. After several days, a colorless blocklike crystalline product appeared and was collected. Yield:  73% (30 mg). 1H NMR (CD3OD):  δ 8.43 (d, 4.0 Hz, 4 H), 7.83 (t, 7.7 Hz, 4 H), 7.44 (d, 7.9 Hz, 4 H), 7.32 (t, 6.5 Hz, 4 H), 2.84 (t, 6.6 Hz, 8 H), 2.13 (m, 4 H) ppm. Anal. Calcd for C26H28Ag2Cl2N4O8:  C, 38.50; H, 3.48; N, 6.91. Found:  C, 38.64; H, 3.46; N, 6.87. Mp:  230 ± 1 °C. MS (FAB) (m/z) for C26H28Ag2N4 calcd 305.0208, obsd 305.0235.

Synthesis of 2. To a solution of L 2 (10 mg, 0.035 mmol) in 4 mL of nitromethane was carefully added a solution of AgClO4 (11 mg, 0.053 mmol) in 4 mL of methanol. The resulting solution was allowed to evaporate in an open test tube. After two weeks, a colorless blocklike crystalline product appeared and was collected. Yield:  23% (5 mg). 1H NMR (CD3OD):  δ 8.64 (s, 6 H), 7.85 (s, 6 H), 7.37 (m, 12 H), 3.07 (m, 2 H) 2.93 (d, 6.3 Hz, 12 H). Anal. Calcd for C38H38Ag3Cl3N6O12:  C, 38.01; H, 3.19; N, 7.00. Found:  C, 37.77; H, 3.30; N, 6.82. Mp:  185 ± 5 °C (dec). MS (FAB) (m/z) for C38H38Ag2N6 calcd 396.06, obsd 396.08.

Synthesis of 3. To a solution of AgNO3 (12 mg, 0.071 mmol) in 4 mL of water was carefully added a solution of L 3 (20 mg, 0.069 mmol) in 4 mL of methanol. The resulting solution was stored in an open test tube. After several days, a colorless crystalline product appeared and was collected. Yield:  88% (28 mg). 1H NMR (D2O):  δ 8.24 (d, 4.8 Hz, 4 H), 7.81 (t, 7.7 Hz, 4 H), 7.35 (m, 8 H), 6.98−6.92 (m, 8 H), 3.68 (q, 7.6 Hz, 2 H), 3.36−3.23 (m, 8 H), 2.20 (s, 6 H). Anal. Calcd for C20H20AgN3O3:  C, 52.42; H, 4.40; N, 9.17. Found:  C, 52.70; H, 4.30; N, 9.11. Mp:  165 ± 1 °C. MS (FAB) (m/z) for C40H40Ag2N4·NO3 calcd 852.1233, obsd 852.1223.

Synthesis of 4. To a solution of AgNO3 (12 mg, 0.071 mmol) in 4 mL of water was added a solution of L 4 (20 mg, 0.073 mmol) in 4 mL of methanol. The resulting solution was stored in an open test tube. After several days, a colorless blocklike crystalline product appeared and was collected. Yield:  78% (25 mg). 1H NMR (D2O):  δ 8.26 (d, 4.2 Hz, 4 H), 7.79 (t, 7.6 Hz, 4 H), 7.33 (m, 8 H), 7.19 (m, 6 H), 7.07 (d, 6.9 Hz, 4 H), 3.73 (q, 7.3 Hz, 2 H), 3.37−3.26 (m, 8 H). Anal. Calcd for C38H36Ag2N6O6:  C, 51.37; H, 4.08; N, 9.46. Found:  C, 51.33; H, 4.00; N, 9.46. Mp:  176 ± 1 °C. MS (FAB) (m/z) for C38H36Ag2N4·NO3 calcd 824.0920, obsd 824.0917.

Yield: 78% (25 mg). 1H NMR (D2O): δ 8.26 (d, 4.2 Hz, 4 H), 7.79 (t, 7.6 Hz, 4 H), 7.33 (m, 8 H), 7.19 (m, 6 H), 7.07 (d, 6.9 Hz, 4 H), 3.73 (q, 7.3 Hz, 2 H), 3.37-3.26 (m, 8 H). Anal. Calcd for C38H36Ag2N6O6: C, 51.37; H, 4.08; N, 9.46. Found: C, 51.33; H, 4.00; N, 9.46. Mp: 176 ± 1 °C. MS (FAB) (m/z) for C38H36Ag2N4⋅NO3 calcd 824.0920, obsd 824.0917.
